results.title: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne's Art Trams
results.creator_credit: Michael Buckley, Arts Victoria and National Heart Foundation of Australia. Victorian Division
results.brief_description: Trams have always been a feature of Melbourne life and they have now been transformed into moving art galleries. Melbourne’s Transporting Art Project involves a new series of decorated trams. Several of the artists discuss their reasons for taking part in the scheme, the themes behind their work and the unusual medium. Artists include Aleks Danko, Philip Faulks, Lin Onus, Terry Matassoni, Jenny Watson and Brett Colquhoun.
results.title_for_label: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne’s Art Trams

results.title: Artists in cyberculture
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Cohen, Frances McGivern and Cracked Metal Productions
results.brief_description: Artists record their work at the Third International Symposium on Electronic Art, Sydney, 1992. Through a series of interviews, performance, electronic theatre, this video looks at ways in which artists challenge the emerging technological realm known as “cyberculture”. It also examines issues such as gender, the body, the homogenisation of culture and the social and environmental implications of new technologies. Three of the artists interviewed are Char Davies, Stelarc and Myron Kreuger.

results.title: Concrete city
results.creator_credit: Fabio Cavadini, Mandy King and Frontyard Films
results.brief_description: This thought-provoking film about a small community of working class people who live in the old wharfside Sydney suburb of Pyrmont, brings into question the notion of coummunity participation in major urban development schemes. The development, in this case, involves nothing less than the total destruction of a community and of valuable heritage sites, for the construction of a casino and a whole range of high rise commercial development. The community is “consulted” and “involved”, yet their own suggestions as to how best develop the area are largely ignored.

results.title: 1993 World solar challenge
results.creator_credit: Don Scutt, GMH and Monash University. Mechanical Engineering, Caulfield
results.brief_description: Covers the 1993 Daido Hoxan World Solar Challenge, a race by solar powered cars from Darwin to Adelaide over 3000 kilometres. Includes interviews with the leading teams and technical experts.

results.title: Sir Jack Brabham: The complete history of a motor racing legend
results.creator_credit: Neville Hay and Hay Fisher Productions
results.brief_description: Brabham - one of the great names in motor racing history. A great driver who not only became a household name worldwide during the 1950’s and 60’s for his driving exploits, but who also created a racing team that was still winning in the 1980’s. This story of Sir Jack Brabham, told exclusively in his own words and by close associates including Stirling Moss, Roy Salvadori and and John Cooper. Extensive archival material captures the feel of some glorious motor racing while tracing every step of a truly brilliant career.

results.title: Spitfire over Australia
results.brief_description: During World War II, more than 650 Spitfire aircraft were delivered to the RAAF. This is the story of Colin Pay, who rebuilt one of those magnificent machines, a Vickers Supermarine Spitfire HF Mk VIII built in 1944, from the corroded hulk he acquired in 1982. It is now a superbly restored flying machine. Including some of the best air to air colour footage ever shot of a Spitfire in Australia, and archival footage of Spitfires in Darwin in 1943 and interviews with the pilots who originally flew them, this is the ideal video for avaition enthusiasts!

results.title: Words and silk
results.creator_credit: John Cruthers, Philip Tyndall and Kangaroo Films
results.brief_description: A two part program about the life and works of Australian fiction writer, Gerald Murnane. Pt. 1. The imaginary and real world of Gerald Murnane (41 min.) The first part explores his imaginary world and presents images both of Murnane’s childhood in Victoria during the 1940’s and of his interests, particularly his obsession with horseracing. Pt. 2. The real and imaginary world of Gerald Murnane (45 min.) In the second part Murnane discusses his writing style and reads extracts from Tamarisk Row to show how he weaves his interests and obsessions into his work.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Cruthers, Philip Tyndall and Kangaroo Films

results.title: Women of the iron frontier
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Fraser Film and Video
results.brief_description: Filmed in the remote Pilbara region in far north Western Australia this is a moving revelation of the struggle of women who are trying to create a life for themselves in the hostile environment of outback iron ore mining towns. “Time goes very slowly” deals with the problems of isolation and unemployment for women in Newman. “It’s not a community anymore” tells of the ongoing effects of the bitter 1986 Robe River industrial dispute upon families in the town of Wickham. “It’s supposed to be a town” explores racism through the eyes of both the black and white women of Newman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lilias Fraser, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Fraser Film and Video

results.title: Steam across the mountains: the story of the Zig Zag Railway
results.creator_credit: Nick A'Hern, ABC Video and Nick A'Hern Productions
results.brief_description: The Zig Zag Railway is regarded as an engineering marvel and a mecca to students of engineering the world over. This fascinating video follows the Zig Zag’s colourful history from its early days in the great commercial steam era, to its closure in 1910 and through to its restoration as a tourist railway in 1975. This program uses the Zig Zag Railway as a working model to bring to life the romance adventure and style of the Great Australian Steam Era. Highlights include: complete stereo soundtrack, breathtaking footage shot entirely on 16mm film and loads of steam trains to see and hear!
results.title_for_label: Steam across the mountains: the story of the Zig Zag Railway
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nick A’Hern, ABC Video and Nick A’Hern Productions

results.title: Steam alive in Victoria: a tribute to steam
results.brief_description: The history of Victoria’s steam trains runs parallel to the history of the state itself. As the railway tracks made their way into the countryside, the state began to develop. Steam locomotives puffing their way into country towns were the life blood of the state, bringing in supplies and visitors and taking away produce and goods. Today the steam locomotives have been replaced. Many were left to rust and decay but a number of them have been restored by dedicated groups of volunteers, determined to preserve this exciting part of our heritage. Steam trains are alive again in Victoria and this magnificent videotape is a tribute to those groups who have kept the locomotives on the tracks to give pleasure to those who love steam travel. You can enjoy the thrill of the journey, the heat of the firebox and the shrill of the whistle as you watch “Steam Alive in Victoria”.
